name: South Sudan
currentCrisisSummary:
South Sudan suffers a severe humanitarian emergency driven by **elite competition over oil revenues**, recurrent **climate catastrophe** (flooding), and spillover from Sudan's war. The state, designed through a flawed **neoliberal peace process**, functions as a battlefield for **oil rents**, facilitated by a complicit **global financial system**.

Simultaneously, **climate extremes** destroy livelihoods, multiplying displacement and hunger. The post-2013 conflict dynamics, rooted in this **predatory political economy**, inflict high mortality. Renewed tensions threaten fragile gains.

The human cost is immense, one of Africa's largest displacement crises. Solutions require dismantling **elite impunity**, ensuring **accountability**, and redirecting **oil wealth** and **international finance** (enabling **kleptocracy**) toward **locally-led recovery** and **climate resilience**.

colonialRoot.legacy:
**British colonial administration** pursued a '**Southern Policy**' governing the south separately, entrenching divisions. This **divide-and-rule** approach limited investment, leaving a legacy of **structural marginalisation** contributing to insurgency.

The administrative boundaries, uneven development, and **externally mediated leadership** created conditions vulnerable to **elite predation** and **resource-capture** post-independence.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal State-Building and the CPA
historicalContext.description: The 2005 **Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA)**, mediated by **Western powers**, was a fundamentally **neoliberal peace-building project**. It prioritised a **market-based, oil-exporting state**, focusing on technocratic elements. This model neglected grassroots reconciliation, failed to diversify the economy, and created a **hollow state** solely for distributing **oil rents**. The 2013 civil war was a predictable outcome of this flawed, **externally-imposed model**.

historicalContext.title: Corruption and the Global Financial System
historicalContext.description: Politics are shaped by an **elite scramble for oil revenue**. The state captures **rents** rather than delivering services. **International banks**, **opaque corporate structures**, and the **global financial system** enable laundering stolen wealth, allowing elites profit while services collapse. This system provides **safe havens for illicit capital**, fuelling conflict. **Financial opacity** and weak due diligence are **structural enablers**.

historicalContext.title: Oil Conflict and Climate Challenges
historicalContext.description: The **oil sector** fuels **rent-seeking**; **foreign energy companies** partnering with elites prioritise **extraction**. Simultaneously, **extreme floods** (worsened by **global heating**) destroy crops and aggravate food insecurity. **Climate shocks** act as a **conflict multiplier**.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Serious violations of **international humanitarian** and **human-rights law** documented. Research estimates large **excess deaths** from the 2013-18 war. Calls for **accountability** include a Hybrid Court and **targeted sanctions**. Effective **accountability** needs criminal responsibility plus **asset recovery** and **resource governance reform**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 400,000 excess deaths since 2013 from violence linked to the **elite struggle over oil wealth**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 9.4 million require aid due to **state failure** engendered by the flawed peace deal and **elite predation**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Massive population faces hunger driven by **conflict**, **climate-induced flooding**, and **state neglect**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 4 million displaced (internal/refugees) by violence linked to **oil control** and **climate events**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 2.3 million refugees forced abroad by chronic conflict and lack of protection inherent in a **kleptocratic state**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions of children denied education due to conflict and **state failure to invest oil revenues**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Extreme Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Majority face extreme poverty, an outcome of **oil wealth looted by elites enabled by global finance**.

timeline.event: **Anglo-Egyptian Condominium**: Britain administered the south under a 'Southern Policy' that separated it administratively from northern Sudan, entrenching regional inequalities.
**First Sudanese Civil War**: Southern rebellions for autonomy and justice begin before Sudan's independence, sowing the seeds of later fragmentation.
**Second Sudanese Civil War**: A brutal renewed war causes mass displacement and millions of deaths, creating conditions for later secession.

**Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA)**: A Western-mediated peace deal establishes a government based on sharing oil revenues. This neoliberal model of state-building creates a state designed for elite rent-capture, laying the groundwork for future conflict.
**Independence**: South Sudan becomes the world's newest state after a referendum, inheriting weak institutions and an oil-dependent economy.
**Civil War Erupts**: Political rivalry between elites escalates into wide-scale violence, producing mass displacement and severe humanitarian collapse.
**Revitalised Peace Agreement**: A fragile power-sharing agreement is signed but many core reforms, notably security-sector reform and accountability measures, remain incomplete.

**Renewed Tensions & Flooding**: Political tensions, contested prosecutions and catastrophic floods in recent years have combined to deepen displacement, food insecurity and protection risks, threatening fragile peace gains.

donate.description: A South Sudanese-led NGO providing emergency relief and community development programmes in contested and hard-to-reach areas.
The national humanitarian society for South Sudan, providing emergency response, health services, and community support to populations affected by conflict and climate change.
Works with children and families affected by conflict to provide education, child protection services, and support for long-term livelihoods.

advocacy.title: Sanction Kleptocrats & Recover Stolen Assets
advocacy.description: Push for targeted sanctions and asset-recovery measures against corrupt elites and intermediaries who divert oil revenues and undermine peace.

advocacy.title: Establish the Hybrid Court
advocacy.description: Advocate for establishment and proper funding of the Hybrid Court for South Sudan to ensure credible accountability for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

advocacy.title: Renegotiate Oil Contracts
advocacy.description: Demand that oil contracts and resource revenues be renegotiated with transparent, community-centred benefit-sharing and robust oversight.

advocacy.title: Fund Local Climate & Humanitarian Action
advocacy.description: Call for scaled, flexible humanitarian and climate finance that is channelled through South Sudanese organisations and local institutions to build resilience.

reading.title: *When Peace Kills Politics: International Intervention and Unending War in the Sudans*
reading.description: Sharath Srinivasan critically analyses how flawed international peace interventions, like the CPA, undermined politics and fuelled conflict in the Sudans.

reading.title: *The Real Politics of the Horn of Africa: Money, War and the Business of Power*
reading.description: Alex de Waal explains the political economy driving conflict in the region, focusing on elite rent-seeking ('kleptocracy') relevant to South Sudan's oil war.

reading.title: *South Sudan: A New History for a New Nation*
reading.description: Douglas H. Johnson provides a crucial historical account of South Sudan's long struggle and the context leading to independence.
